headline: International women's day: a voice from Eldoret, Kenya
text: When the other pupils at school first found out I was HIV positive, when I was around 15, it was really tough. I used to have a lot of friends. But they would all say, 'The day I find out I'm positive, I'll kill myself', or 'The day I find out my friend is positive, I'll run away from her.' They ran away from me. I had no friends. Nobody would touch my books; they were afraid that, if they did, they would get the disease. In the canteen no one would touch what I'd touched. It was the hardest time of my life, even compared to the day I was raped. I felt like nobody in this world loved me, that I was alone. I didn't want to go back to school, but I had to. I want to be able to earn enough to feed and support my Mum like she's supported me. I had stopped taking my ARVs [antiretrovirals]. After all, I thought, I'm positive, and I'm going to die. But my mum told me we had to be strong for each other. I realised there's no way I can stop living. I have to be Vida. I have to accept the fact that I was raped and I'm HIV positive. In my school there were other pupils who were positive who hadn't accepted the fact. The teachers said: 'Vida, you have to tell them that they have to go on with life, they have to be strong.' So I speak about my life twice a week for 40 minutes. Coming out of stigma is not an easy thing, so you have to do it over and over again. I'm trying to show them the positive side of being positive  that you can smile every day. You have to take control of HIV  you can't let it control you. It can't take away any part of you. I'm comfortable again these days. I have friends again  a lot of friends. I want to be a lawyer, so that I can give justice to those that haven't received it; the justice I was really crying for. If I could get justice, the monster would be out of me. But in Kenya you can't get justice if you don't have cash. Somewhere else a girl is going through what I went through that day. It's the worst thing that could happen to an innocent child.
